Articles.Content:
7 hours ago, mystifeid said:

I got all inspired to try the boost flap controller but the add-on releases thread has been closed (says that BFC is discontinued) and all the links are dead. No more BFC?

So is it still a requirement for engines to be shut down while airborne?

I believe so. In the Dakar rally I couldn't use BFC because my design was weird, so I just set the flaps (or in my case service bay) to toggle on the brake action group and then made sure to hit the brakes as I was leaving the ground and released as I landed.  BFC just made that so much more convenient and ensured you never miss the timing.

 

5 hours ago, GDJ said:

I PM'd @DoctorDavinci to see how he's doing but no response as of now.﻿

I'd also pm'd him as we were mid conversation about something else, but he's just vanished.

 

4 hours ago, purpleivan said:

The link put up a few days ago seems to be dead, but based on the BFC thread @katateochi has the latest version.﻿

yeah, I've got the latest release. The BFC thread says it's licence is GPLv3, and my understanding of that is that it permits others to distribute the work.  I don't have the source code, just the compiled end product.  I'd be happy to share the latest release version with my fellow racers,  do you think it would be OK for me to do that? (I'd like a nod from someone who knows, before I put my foot in it!). I wouldn't setup a thread to post it, just respond with a link to anyone who PMs me.

@katateochi Nice !

Are you up for a polar rally ?

 

Edited September 10, 2018 by Triop

3 hours ago, Triop said:

Are you up for a polar rally ?

I.....I'm not sure I'm crazy enough. A couple weeks ago I drove about 150km on Mun and that was the longest in-one-sitting drive I've ever done. Never really been tempted by the idea of a long haul......that being said, the one thing I've not tested on ExplorerX is how far it can go on 1 tank of gas.  This might be the opportunity to test that! I see you're driving a solar powered rover, if we used an LF/O-fuelcell powered rover could we airdrop fuel when needed or setup gas stations along the way?

21 minutes ago, katateochi said:

I.....I'm not sure I'm crazy enough.

Well, you don't have to do it nonstop, you can drive for a bit, stop, and go back to the space center and return later. (no quicksave)

But it is pretty cool to do it in one go if you have the time.

21 minutes ago, katateochi said:

if we used an LF/O-fuelcell powered rover could we airdrop fuel when needed or setup gas stations along the way?

Yes, I'm all for that.

It doesn't have to be only solar powered.

But remember, your time starts as soon as you start a new game, so you have to strategically time placing your fueltanks.

* EDIT: It is the fastest option, I'm doing this solar and lose 2-4 hours a day waiting to recharge batteries, in that time it would be possible to drop fuel on multiple waypoints without losing time against solar drivers

 

For more info:

 

Edited September 10, 2018 by Triop

Not long ago I circumnavigated Kerbin (mainly by land). I started from the Dessert launch site, went south to the south pole then north to the north pole and then finally south again back to the start. Several small water crossings were made and my route was as circular and direct as I could make it. Both on land and on the water I tried to maintain 40-50m/s but in some places this was not possible. I'm pretty sure this took me in excess of thirty hours so going from one pole to another took me at least fifteen hours. But I was just trying to make it - forget about speed. Let's say you go twice as fast or even four times as fast and that's still a significant chunk of time for one sitting. Hoping you don't make a mistake and wreck your over.

Are you even allowed to cross water?

17 minutes ago, mystifeid said:

Are you even allowed to cross water?

I assume you are talking about the Pole2Pole challenge (that is under construction)

This is no circumnavigation, well, half it is....

No serious water needs crossing...

21 minutes ago, Triop said:

No serious water needs crossing

Just asking because a hydrofoil (with wheels for the beginning/end) that maybe has one or two fuel dumps is going to take a much more direct route and is going to be able to maintain 100+m/s.

I decided to take a break from my first ever (career) game in ksp and startet my first ever sandbox game to copy this save file into....

...so many firsts...

- first ever sandbox game
- first ever challenge to take on
- first ever cargo plane to transport a rover
- first ever rover delivered by cargo plane

I am very pleased with the result









Edit: Just saw I had MET on on the landing shot...sorry about that, just write "ridiculously long anyway"

Edited September 10, 2018 by Stunkfish

1 hour ago, vitekc45c said:

What a cute buggy.

I've started testing my rocket car. I warped it over to the desert airfield today and did a trial run of the course.

The test was very informative, as I learned that the Rocket Racer has a huge over steering problem, and that it has great potential, having traversed over half the course in about 4 minutes despite several spin-outs. I've recovered the crew, but decided to leave the vehicle were it crashed.
